title: 112_hr4234
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" amends the terms of grazing permits and leases to extend the duration to 20 years. It also includes provisions for the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" extends the duration of grazing permits and leases to 20 years and includes provisions for their renewal, transfer, and reissuance under SEC. 405. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" defines current grazing management and the Secretary concerned, and addresses renewal, transfer, reissuance, and pending processing of grazing permits or leases. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" outlines the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits or leases under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Interior or the Department of Agriculture for National Forest System land. The terms and conditions of expired permits are subject to renewal under specific sections of relevant acts. The terms and conditions of expired grazing permits or leases can be renewed, transferred, or reissued under specific sections of relevant acts. The renewed or reissued permit or lease will continue with the same terms and conditions until processing is completed by the Secretary concerned. Cancellation, suspension, or modification of the permit or lease can still occur in accordance with applicable law. The Secretary concerned can cancel, suspend, or modify permits or leases as per applicable law. After processing, permits or leases can be renewed or reissued for a 20-year term. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer may be exempt from environmental assessment if it continues current grazing management. The decision to renew, reissue, or transfer grazing management may be exempt from environmental assessment if it aligns with land use objectives and department policies. The Secretary determines the priority and timing for completing environmental analyses. The Secretary has the discretion to prioritize and determine the timing for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on environmental significance and available funding. NEPA exemptions include crossing/trailing authorizations of livestock and transfer of grazing preference. Sec. 405 addresses the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases.
